content: @Eric Huss I think I'll have some time to help push <https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/7722> (config-cli) over the finish line in the coming weeks, but would need some guidance from you on the implications of the unresolved issue (see <https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/7722#issuecomment-977288181>) when you get the time :)

Gentle nudge that <https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/10176> has now been switched to using toml_edit for the parsing/validation. I'm hoping that it might now be feasible to land, which (at least in theory) would unblock config-cli!
Gentle nudge on <https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/10176> @Eric Huss â€” it now uses toml_edit for parsing :+1:
btw I just released v0.12.2 which should have fixes for almost all of the regressions I found when porting cargo over to it. Tomorrow I'll be double checking in case I missed anything.
I'll get to it when I can. However, I would prefer not to add a new dependency until cargo#10086 is resolved, so it may need to wait on that.
Any remaining blockers for config-cli now that the format checking was merged? None are listed on the tracking issue, but figured you may have some more in mind?
I can't think of any. I'd like to test out the latest changes on nightly, but otherwise I don't think there are any blockers.
I don't currently have a need for config-include, but definitely not unthinkable that it might come in handy. I can already think of some things it might make easier. Why?

One of the major motivators here was --config otherfile.toml to make it easy to swap between different configs. It might be nice to stabilize them at the same time since they are interrelated. But it's not critical.
I could probably find some time to help push that forward. Do you have the tracking issue handy? Is there a list of blockers?

cargo#7723

There is some open design space, and some general questions about its usefulness. It was somewhat modeled after git's include, but not as flexible. The tracking issue also has a comment from someone with some ideas.

I don't think it is a priority to stabilize it. Another option is to just stabilize --config PATH but leave the include stuff for later.

I definitely see this as orthogonal to --config, and see --config PATH as something that could be stabilized with just config-cli. I'll try to muster some time to iterate on the include bits, but I don't think it's worth blocking config-cli on, esp. since I may not get to it for a little while.
